articles.headline: Plan to Storm Fence Gets Bloody Preview in Gaza
articles.snippet: After hundreds of Palestinian protesters attacked the fence between Israel and Gaza, Israeli troops opened fire, killing four and wounding hundreds.
articles.abstract: After hundreds of Palestinian protesters attacked the fence between Israel and Gaza, Israeli troops opened fire, killing four and wounding hundreds.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — For weeks, Palestinians protesting along the fence between Gaza and Israel have conjured up the idea of swarming across the barrier, a mass of tens of thousands of people too numerous for Israeli soldiers to arrest or even to shoot.
articles.byline: By Iyad Abuheweila and David M. Halbfinger

articles.headline: Why Airline Credit Cards Have an Enduring Appeal
articles.snippet: While the math of frequent-flier miles may not always add up, perks like free checked bags have people flocking to travel cards.
articles.abstract: While the math of frequent-flier miles may not always add up, perks like free checked bags have people flocking to travel cards.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s been more than 30 years since the first credit card offering frequent-flier miles made its debut, so you’d think that the market for plastic passports bearing the promise of free trips would be mature by now.

articles.headline: Sprint and T-Mobile Are Said to Be Close to a Merger to Compete at the Top
articles.snippet: A deal would create the third-largest wireless company in the United States, behind AT&T and Verizon.
articles.abstract: A deal would create the third-largest wireless company in the United States, behind AT&T and Verizon.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sprint and T-Mobile are hoping to get it right this time.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: Firing of House Chaplain Causes Uproar on Capitol Hill
articles.snippet: Speaker Paul D. Ryan, who requested the resignation of the Rev. Patrick J. Conroy, is facing pushback from his own party as well as Democrats.
articles.abstract: Speaker Paul D. Ryan, who requested the resignation of the Rev. Patrick J. Conroy, is facing pushback from his own party as well as Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: Speaker Paul D. Ryan’s abrupt decision to dismiss the House chaplain triggered an uproar on Friday over religion, pitting Republican against Republican and offering Democrats a political opportunity in a year already moving their way.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Dias and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Koreans Set the Table for a Deal That Trump Will Try to Close
articles.snippet: North and South Korea agreed to seek denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula, but President Trump and North Korea’s leader now have many details to iron out.
articles.abstract: North and South Korea agreed to seek denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula, but President Trump and North Korea’s leader now have many details to iron out.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Rush-hour in South Korea’s over-caffeinated capital runs at a frenzy — so it was remarkable to see commuters freeze Friday morning and fixate on giant Samsung television screens showing the scene unfolding in the Demilitarized Zone, where time stopped in 1953.

articles.headline: Cosby Verdict Is Hailed a Breakthrough. Here’s Why It Was an Anomaly.
articles.snippet: #MeToo flooded the world with reports of sexual assault. But it did not wash away the legal hurdles to proving it.
articles.abstract: #MeToo flooded the world with reports of sexual assault. But it did not wash away the legal hurdles to proving it.
articles.lead_paragraph: The guilty verdict against Bill Cosby was hailed by some as long overdue.

articles.headline: Bob Dylan’s Latest Gig: Making Whiskey
articles.snippet: A move into the booming celebrity-branded spirits market is yet another career twist for an artist who has spent five decades confounding expectations.
articles.abstract: A move into the booming celebrity-branded spirits market is yet another career twist for an artist who has spent five decades confounding expectations.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late 2015, an unexpected name popped up in the liquor industry press: Bob Dylan.

articles.headline: Doris Burke Has Game
articles.snippet: The ESPN personality, the first female full-time analyst on national N.B.A. broadcasts, has broken one of the highest glass ceilings in TV. So why does her status still feel so precarious?
articles.abstract: The ESPN personality, the first female full-time analyst on national N.B.A. broadcasts, has broken one of the highest glass ceilings in TV. So why does her status still feel so precarious?
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — In mid-April, on the last day of the N.B.A.’s regular season, a group of reporters gathered at the Wells Fargo Center here, buzzing with an urgent question: Would Giannis Antetokounmpo, the Milwaukee Bucks’ impossibly elastic 6-foot-11 phenom, be in the lineup that night?

articles.headline: Trump’s Role in Midterm Elections Roils Republicans
articles.snippet: G.O.P. leaders and White House aides are trying to prepare the president for trouble in House and Senate races. But he is rejecting their grim prognoses and wants to start campaigning.
articles.abstract: G.O.P. leaders and White House aides are trying to prepare the president for trouble in House and Senate races. But he is rejecting their grim prognoses and wants to start campaigning.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump is privately rejecting the growing consensus among Republican leaders that they may lose the House and possibly the Senate in November, leaving party officials and the president’s advisers nervous that he does not grasp the gravity of the threat they face in the midterm elections.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin, Alexander Burns and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: The Golden State Killer Left a Trail of Horror With Taunts and Guile
articles.snippet: How a serial rapist and murderer in California flaunted his power as well as his belief that he could elude accountability forever. He was wrong.
articles.abstract: How a serial rapist and murderer in California flaunted his power as well as his belief that he could elude accountability forever. He was wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Throughout 1977, the terrified residents of Sacramento County wanted to know when their horror movie of an existence would end. In packed community forums, they expressed their fears about the sadistic predator who was committing sexual assaults in their previously tranquil neighborhoods every few days — someone nicknamed the East Area Rapist.
articles.byline: By Dan Barry, Tim Arango and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: As Two Koreas Talk Peace, Trump’s Bargaining Chips Slip Away
articles.snippet: The overtures between North and South Korea will inevitably erode crippling economic sanctions and make it harder for President Trump to threaten military action.
articles.abstract: The overtures between North and South Korea will inevitably erode crippling economic sanctions and make it harder for President Trump to threaten military action.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump lost no time hailing the historic nature of Friday’s meeting between the leaders of North and South Korea. But the gauzy images and vows of peace by Kim Jong-un and his counterpart from the South, Moon Jae-in, have complicated Mr. Trump’s task as he prepares for his own history-making encounter with Mr. Kim.

articles.headline: At Nike, Revolt Led by Women Leads to Exodus of Male Executives
articles.snippet: Complaints about bad behavior by men and a lack of advancement for women long went ignored, employees said, but now change seems to be afoot.
articles.abstract: Complaints about bad behavior by men and a lack of advancement for women long went ignored, employees said, but now change seems to be afoot.
articles.lead_paragraph: For too many women, life inside Nike had turned toxic.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell, Kevin Draper and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: Pope Francis in the Wilderness
articles.snippet: As he remakes the church in his image, Francis finds himself more isolated, as global political trends shift and he meets resistance to his reforms.
articles.abstract: As he remakes the church in his image, Francis finds himself more isolated, as global political trends shift and he meets resistance to his reforms.
articles.lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Five years ago, Pope Francis was elected to be an agent of change within a church shaken by scandals and the historic resignation of Benedict XVI. He quickly became a global force in geopolitics, setting the agenda on climate change and care for migrants. World leaders wanted to be near him. Even non-Catholics adored him.

articles.headline: Kim Says He’d End North Korea Nuclear Pursuit for U.S. Truce
articles.snippet: South Korean officials said the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, had told them he would abandon his nuclear weapons if Washington ended the Korean War and promised nonaggression.
articles.abstract: South Korean officials said the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, had told them he would abandon his nuclear weapons if Washington ended the Korean War and promised nonaggression.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Keeping diplomatic developments coming at a head-snapping pace, the South Korean government said on Sunday that North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, had told President Moon Jae-in that he would abandon his nuclear weapons if the United States agreed to formally end the Korean War and promise not to invade his country.

articles.headline: Michelle Wolf Sets Off a Furor at White House Correspondents’ Dinner
articles.snippet: Remarks about Sarah Huckabee Sanders opened a partisan divide in an awkward evening of comedy and politics.
articles.abstract: Remarks about Sarah Huckabee Sanders opened a partisan divide in an awkward evening of comedy and politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The panna cotta had been served and the First Amendment duly celebrated by the time the comedian Michelle Wolf took the stage on Saturday at the White House Correspondents’ Association dinner.

articles.headline: Sprint and T-Mobile to Merge, in Bid to Remake Wireless Market
articles.snippet: The two companies are betting that regulators will finally allow the American wireless market to shrink to just three national players.
articles.abstract: The two companies are betting that regulators will finally allow the American wireless market to shrink to just three national players.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sprint and T-Mobile announced on Sunday that they had reached a deal to merge, moving to create a new telecommunications giant — and betting that regulators will finally allow the American wireless market to shrink to just three national players.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: Migrant Caravan of Asylum Seekers Reaches U.S. Border
articles.snippet: Hundreds of migrants who have traveled en masse through Mexico, drawing a furious response from President Trump, prepared to apply for asylum.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of migrants who have traveled en masse through Mexico, drawing a furious response from President Trump, prepared to apply for asylum.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIJUANA, Mexico — A long, grueling journey gave way to what could be a long, uncertain asylum process Sunday as a caravan of immigrants finally reached the border between the United States and Mexico, setting up a dramatic moment and a test of President Trump’s anti-immigrant politics.
articles.byline: By Kirk Semple and Miriam Jordan

articles.headline: U.S. Allies Brace for Trade War as Tariff Negotiations Stall
articles.snippet: Days before Trump tariffs on steel and aluminum take effect, negotiators for producing countries see themselves at the mercy of the president’s whims.
articles.abstract: Days before Trump tariffs on steel and aluminum take effect, negotiators for producing countries see themselves at the mercy of the president’s whims.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A few weeks ago, it felt as if a trade war pitting the United States against allies like Australia, Canada and the European Union was over before it even began. The Trump administration dispensed so many temporary exemptions to steel and aluminum tariffs that many countries figured the threats were just political theater.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: Blockchain Will Be Theirs, Russian Spy Boasted at Conference
articles.snippet: Some think the technology that was introduced with Bitcoin has enormous potential. That has a number of countries looking to influence its future.
articles.abstract: Some think the technology that was introduced with Bitcoin has enormous potential. That has a number of countries looking to influence its future.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last year, representatives of 25 countries met in Tokyo to work on setting international standards for the blockchain, the technology that was introduced by the virtual currency Bitcoin and has ignited intense interest in corporate and government circles.

articles.headline: One Goal of Amazon’s HQ2: Learn the Lessons of Seattle
articles.snippet: Amazon has surprised officials in cities vying for the company’s new headquarters by asking how to avoid soaring housing costs and paralyzing traffic.
articles.abstract: Amazon has surprised officials in cities vying for the company’s new headquarters by asking how to avoid soaring housing costs and paralyzing traffic.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — When 10 representatives from Amazon visited the Denver area in late January, they did what you’d expect from a company scouting for a place to put its second headquarters. They toured more than a half-dozen potential sites for a new campus and talked about the technical talent available in the area.

articles.headline: Left vs. Left: Richard Cordray and Dennis Kucinich Battle for Governor of Ohio
articles.snippet: The state’s Democratic primary raises the question: Who has the truest claim to progressivism in 2018, when both candidates can credibly grab at the label?
articles.abstract: The state’s Democratic primary raises the question: Who has the truest claim to progressivism in 2018, when both candidates can credibly grab at the label?
articles.lead_paragraph: AKRON, Ohio — Richard Cordray speaks softly and carries a big stack: lime-green index cards, pressed into his shirt pocket, near enough for any sudden onset of note-taking.

articles.headline: For Gaza Protester, Living or Dying Is the ‘Same Thing’
articles.snippet: Hope is a scarce commodity in Gaza, which is little more than an open-air prison. A look at how one man ended up at the bloody protests against Israel.
articles.abstract: Hope is a scarce commodity in Gaza, which is little more than an open-air prison. A look at how one man ended up at the bloody protests against Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — No one would ever pick out Saber al-Gerim from the crowds of Palestinians demonstrating against Israel along the heavily guarded fence that has helped turn the Gaza Strip into an open-air prison.
articles.byline: By Iyad Abuheweila and David M. Halbfinger
